document.title: AP®  Physics C: Mechanics COURSE AND EXAM DESCRIPTION

6D21C16ECE8D410AB633935FB1CE67E4.description:
A torsion pendulum is a case of SHM where
the restoring torque is proportional to the
angular displacement of a rotating system. For
example, a horizontal disk that is suspended
from a wire attached to its center of mass may
undergo rotational oscillations about the wire in
the horizontal plane.

E8927D58C6C745B7B9D8A1664F02E6BE.description:
A simple pendulum is a special case of physical
pendulums in which the hanging object can be
modeled as a point mass at a distance, l, from
the pivot point.

1FFDAC338D5C4400B0521B758C401812.description:
The small-angle approximation and
Newton’s second law in rotational form
yield a second-order differential equation
that describes SHM:

02F9892B4FE54709A9B1992B28FFC345.description:
For small amplitudes of motion, the smallangle approximation can be applied to the
restoring torque.

7D3A2410781E4E8EA71DFC4D68FB31DD.description:
When displaced from equilibrium, the
gravitational force exerted on a physical
pendulum’s center of mass provides a
restoring torque.

153A471D2A5149C29431E0DA061C5C89.description:
For small amplitudes of motion, the period of a
physical pendulum is derived from the application
of Newton’s second law in rotational form.

ACDD518AB6354339AEF43B020967CD6D.description:
A physical pendulum is a rigid body that
undergoes oscillation about a fixed axis.

8044BCF9F77241589A5EB4300018D1D3.description:
Describe the properties of a
physical pendulum.

727ABC3DB9C142469D9FA1E924EA19E5.description:
hanging the amplitude of a system
exhibiting SHM will change the maximum
potential energy of the system and,
therefore, the total energy of the system.

5B79671F4ABD4EBAB522601C8E8161E7.description:
The minimum kinetic energy of a system
exhibiting SHM is zero.

82ECBE7B61854252802E0D4060339C71.description:
The potential energy of a system exhibiting
SHM is at a maximum when the system’s
kinetic energy is at a minimum.

02CBDC003BF64D39926A2BEDB7E1CB46.description:
The kinetic energy of a system exhibiting SHM
is at a maximum when the system’s potential
energy is at a minimum.

088FB66D913149B49861D377372643EC.description:
Conservation of energy indicates that the total
energy of a system exhibiting SHM is constant.

467424566F7940D19C85CC02B92E3FC2.description:
The total energy of a system exhibiting SHM is
the sum of the system’s kinetic and potential
energies.

A3227621D8E64F7EA1BF1EF1187EE40F.description:
Describe the mechanical
energy of a system exhibiting
SHM.

7CADC0461D644ABE9F54C1F810F32C55.description:
Properties of SHM can be determined and
analyzed using graphical representations.

DFCB7DF622B04386BC8E940E579839E0.description:
Changing the amplitude of a system exhibiting
SHM will not change its period.

C77C0364439D4581AA08238D87C8F194.description:
The natural frequency of a system is the
frequency at which the system will oscillate
when it is displaced from its equilibrium
position.

0DCD843AF27A4764BE1ECA9762929A79.description:
Resonance increases the amplitude of
oscillating motion.

A5D0F0CDF54546459D7814EC48A3C5D1.description:
Resonance occurs when an external force
is exerted at the natural frequency of an
oscillating system.

59D9F675627B47A8AE60C171BCBEBFD7.description:
In the presence of a sinusoidal external force, a
system may exhibit resonance.

5C284A74D6F84FC9AF648B9A3C96A505.description:
It can be shown that the maximum velocity
and acceleration of an object exhibiting
SHM are related to the angular frequency of
the object’s motion.

28C1282453B34155ACEE970A0A1CCDAC.description:
The acceleration of an object exhibiting
SHM is related to the object’s angular
frequency and position.

CD410F47D0E743FDB10CDBA66A8BF932.description:
Characteristics of SHM, such as velocity and
acceleration, can be determined by or derived
from the equation
x A= + cos( ) ω φ t .

90CF295E9E2E45DBB769086618A1EA55.description:
The position as a function of time for an object
exhibiting SHM is a solution of the secondorder differential equation derived from the
application of Newton’s second law.

7A28F01CF3A0420F881D01C4F2316B87.description:
Recognizing the positions or times at
which the displacement, velocity, and
acceleration for SHM have extrema or zeros
can help in qualitatively describing the
behavior of the motion.

A56ACAC7586C40DB95F102EFF8826319.description:
Minima, maxima, and zeros of
displacement, velocity, and acceleration are
features of harmonic motion.

EAC46095680D46CC941FB3DCC00176BB.description:
For an object exhibiting SHM, the displacement
of that object measured from its equilibrium
position can be represented by the equations
x A= cos 2( ) π ft or x A= sin 2( ) π ft .

6FCD4AC6F5D9487D889B71A46A49D22E.description:
Describe the displacement,
velocity, and acceleration of
an object exhibiting SHM.

The period of a simple pendulum displaced
by a small angle is given by the equation

405EB2EAC7124EBEB1002DD8A3FEFB73.description:
The period of an object– ideal– spring
oscillator is given by the equation

EED405FF16EC44BAA2F8C9DF0D004FA9.description:
The period of SHM is related to the angular
frequency, ω, of the object’s motion by the
following equation:

DAA95246E4CC4311A603BBE8C33C9ED8.description:
Describe the frequency and
period of an object exhibiting
SHM.

82BDF0CFB1CE4A0990B2831E24B343D6.description:
An equilibrium position is a location at
which the net force exerted on an object or
system is zero.

0C3243B3AFCB4AB8A9E067189F9138FC.description:
A restoring force is a force that is exerted
in a direction opposite to the object’s
displacement from an equilibrium position.

24F9DE3A80794A049C2FE310A2360B37.description:
SHM results when the magnitude of the
restoring force exerted on an object is
proportional to that object’s displacement from
its equilibrium position.

9852CE3BC9164D0EBA69C92B8AF9998F.description:
Simple harmonic motion is a special case of
periodic motion.

C01722AC7B2948538351A1D8F2EA50DC.description:
The escape velocity of a satellite from a
central body of mass M can be derived
using conservation of energy laws.

59A9BE42F32046C5BADB1BD83C1B074D.description:
When the only force exerted on a satellite
is gravity from a central object, a satellite
that reaches escape velocity will move
away from the central body until its speed
reaches zero at an infinite distance from the
central body.

8BA836DBAD4045B08856A10DD51E55E3.description:
The escape velocity of a satellite is the
satellite’s velocity such that the mechanical
energy of the satellite–central-object system is
equal to zero.

298B8ACFE74843B894C8891A213F0B77.description:
The total energy of a system consisting of a
satellite orbiting a central object in a circular
path can be written in terms of the gravitational
potential energy of that system or the kinetic
energy of the satellite.

A7075A54D56349A4ACDC811B6CD64C4A.description:
The gravitational potential energy of a
system consisting of a satellite and a
massive central object is defined to be zero
when the satellite is an infinite distance
from the central object.

941022B962DC408FAC96386455CF4624.description:
In elliptical orbits, the system’s total
mechanical energy and the satellite’s
angular momentum are constant, but the
system’s gravitational potential energy
and the satellite’s kinetic energy can each
change.

ED64029A305D4658A3DF53E733272FEA.description:
In circular orbits, the system’s total
mechanical energy, the system’s
gravitational potential energy, and the
satellite’s angular momentum and kinetic
energy are constant.

830ED68D5A894A369B7592A71273F5D1.description:
The motion of satellites in orbits is constrained
by conservation laws.

32A717AE64D54142B8D21317DD027D68.description:
In a system consisting only of a massive central
object and an orbiting satellite with mass that is
negligible in comparison to the central object’s
mass, the motion of the central object itself is
negligible.

FE26E110B0D741BB88826614DA7A713C.description:
Describe the motions of
a system consisting of
two objects or systems
interacting only via
gravitational forces.

EA7E166C8B69409E8B597BD8847811EB.description:
When a rotating system is slipping relative to
another surface, the point of application of the
force of kinetic friction exerted on the system
moves with respect to the surface, so the force
of kinetic friction will dissipate energy from the
system.

F7AC4E260A0E44B1AADFFF09284ECD22.description:
When slipping, the motion of a system’s center
of mass and the system’s rotational motion
cannot be directly related.

B9958523C0334648834A4AC9F27C3BC3.description:
Describe the motion of a
system that is rolling while
slipping.

5FE4CEA2B13644FAA6C173F3ACEE8985.description:
For ideal cases, rolling without slipping implies
that the frictional force does not dissipate any
energy from the rolling system.

19DFA943CA684EE181B382174681C1DC.description:
While rolling without slipping, the translational
motion of a system’s center of mass is related
to the rotational motion of the system itself
with the following equations: ∆ = cm ∆θ
v r cm = ω
a r cm = α

D4224824F42D4520B8D489682AE57BDB.description:
Describe the motion of a
system that is rolling without
slipping.

02FEC7786C654E389FBE999771FEA14E.description:
The total kinetic energy of a system is the sum
of the system’s translational and rotational
kinetic energies.

946F683447914128948222A07F893004.description:
Describe the kinetic energy
of a system that has
translational and rotational
motion.

6860C2814B004328BFDBF324E269C16C.description:
If the net external torque exerted on a selected
object or rigid system is nonzero, angular
momentum is transferred between the system
and the environment.

D1599DD62C5F4C0290733CF43AD74C46.description:
If the net external torque exerted on a selected
object or rigid system is zero, the total angular
momentum of that system is constant.

0217D7C4B1EE4EABA4F0FB54EBDF146C.description:
Angular momentum is conserved in all
interactions.

A1C1922C29C9451E8B9B68E735AB05AD.description:
Describe how the selection of
a system determines whether
the angular momentum of
that system changes.

1B725A35DF4C4B5786F37B991B1AD415.description:
If the total angular momentum of a system
changes, that change will be equivalent to
the angular impulse exerted on the system.

947653A64D8D46D7A412656240408698.description:
The angular speed of a nonrigid,
system may change without the angular
momentum of the system changing if the
system changes shape by moving mass
closer to or farther from the rotational axis.

877D90FF3192434BB87F2F87F8D3EFF1.description:
A system may be selected so that the
total angular momentum of that system is
constant.

96255D58A66341A09A686AFE12466789.description:
The angular impulse exerted by one object
or system on a second object or system is
equal and opposite to the angular impulse
exerted by the second object or system on
the first. This is a direct result of Newton’s
third law.

4F87214F210F408D860A633A633B6124.description:
Any change to a system’s angular momentum
must be due to an interaction between the
system and its surroundings.

9360DA9B7D384D4B86953B5D109CDD6C.description:
The total angular momentum of a system
about a rotational axis is the sum of the angular
momenta of the system’s constituent parts
about that rotational axis.

C974C5CD3FF549C9B911A7165C91170D.description:
Describe the behavior of a
system using conservation of
angular momentum.

58470186A9A44821A8AF544C630577F4.description:
The angular impulse delivered to an object
or rigid system is equal to the area under the
curve of a graph of the net external torque
exerted on an object as a function of time.

1EF439E9EE3642C0800A11420BB8B6A0.description:
The net torque exerted on an object or rigid
system is equal to the slope of the graph of the
angular momentum of an object as a function
of time.

2F35F258A5384A12A30588C7BA88DCBB.description:
The rotational form of the impulse–
momentum theorem is a direct result of
Newton’s second law of motion for cases in
which rotational inertia is constant.

B320420B7B094CCB9CCBD84868814228.description:
The angular impulse exerted on an object
or rigid system is equal to the change in
angular momentum of that object or rigid
system.

2211CD4A1233464D8553F51D82205140.description:
A rotational form of the impulse–momentum
theorem relates the angular impulse delivered
to an object or rigid system and the change
in angular momentum of that object or rigid
system.

237C6F9D3130459F9090029363B41BBD.description:
The magnitude of the change in angular
momentum can be described by comparing
the magnitudes of the final and initial momenta
of the object or rigid system.
∆ = L L − L0

DF9A94CA6C614817BADF0BFDE84FA45F.description:
Relate the change in angular
momentum of an object or
rigid system to the angular
impulse given to that object
or rigid system.

E4F0C8B42A8D42CEABA1AE41DB6CF59E.description:
The angular impulse delivered to an object or
rigid system by a torque can be found from the
area under the curve of a graph of the torque
as a function of time.

6C58674D4C9148908A575C1F6208AEAA.description:
Angular impulse has the same direction as the
torque imparting it.

438600CF543349009CC4D72597596989.description:
Angular impulse is defined as the product of
the torque exerted on an object or rigid system
and the time interval during which the torque is
exerted.

9BAF330135EC45B58F5B9A474696EDDB.description:
Describe the angular impulse
delivered to an object or rigid
system by a torque.

34114BCCA71143C193856F1B80BC29B8.description:
The measured angular momentum of an
object traveling in a straight line depends
on the distance between the reference
point and the object, the mass of the
object, the speed of the object, and the
angle between the radial distance and the
velocity of the object.

534DA1FBA2C443CEADEAA616DAAD6022.description:
The selection of the axis about which an
object is considered to rotate influences
the determination of the angular
momentum of that object.

2815E07AD12B44AA86F5072B14A33E7F.description:
The angular momentum of an object about a
given point is
L r = × p   
.

B59BC2A5857D481A9074E9B1BEB84E15.description:
The magnitude of the angular momentum of
a rigid system about a specific axis can be
described with the equation
L I = ω.

7492A8BE1A654DD18A5985B431C4D8F4.description:
Describe the angular
momentum of an object or
rigid system.

A4E0DBB4F1124F30997F266FC4A325A3.description:
Work done on a rigid system by a given torque
can be found from the area under the curve of
a graph of the torque as a function of angular
position.

E111DC7D8D67456F85AE77578CC57CC4.description:
The amount of work done on a rigid system
by a torque is related to the magnitude of that
torque and the angular displacement through
which the rigid system rotates during the
interval in which that torque is exerted.

A9BDAAEDAE1946C78E3D2B57E6B8600A.description:
A torque can transfer energy into or out of an
object or rigid system if the torque is exerted
over an angular displacement.

E5D66E4E82864B61A3B0ADB74FA66098.description:
Describe the work done on
a rigid system by a given
torque or collection of
torques.

40359B70FB0A42EEA281D51CB1BC86B9.description: Rotational kinetic energy is a scalar quantity

9D5B479FBF004F64B8709C4CE42A7105.description:
A rigid system can have rotational kinetic
energy while its center of mass is at rest due
to the individual points within the rigid system
having linear speed and, therefore, kinetic
energy.

5B480A2989054D9ABAF43D6E649B68B7.description:
The total kinetic energy of a rigid system is
the sum of its rotational kinetic energy due
to its rotation about its center of mass and
the translational kinetic energy due to the
linear motion of its center of mass.

A0AC2F756C8C4525A7A4ADD51FE964B1.description:
The rotational inertia of an object about
a fixed axis can be used to show that the
rotational kinetic energy of that object is
equivalent to its translational kinetic energy,
which is its total kinetic energy.

D0F5C9074438448EABED58C0761FBF21.description:
The rotational kinetic energy of an object or
rigid system is related to the rotational inertia
and angular velocity of the rigid system and is
given by the equation

D597F1669FBD4299B6E08D791C9440AD.description:
Describe the rotational
kinetic energy of a rigid
system in terms of the
rotational inertia and angular
velocity of that rigid system.

AD09FFD388114C6D943D7AC4B005DA9C.description:
Unit 6: Energy and
Momentum
of Rotating
Systems

560C685F8F6C4F038283561DEFBB4D11.description:
To fully describe a rotating rigid system,
linear and rotational analyses may need to be
performed independently

CC1D0FE637234AFBA83FCA0545607C2A.description:
The rate at which the angular velocity of a rigid
system changes is directly proportional to the
net torque exerted on the rigid system and is in
the same direction. The angular acceleration of
the rigid system is inversely proportional to the
rotational inertia of the rigid system.

B417F228464343EEB5D07E9B378E9DF6.description:
Angular velocity changes when the net torque
exerted on the object or system is not equal to
zero.

E0EAB9B7B037405B9E8F222B37D6F28F.description:
Describe the conditions
under which a system’s
angular velocity changes.

E5F108A0BE824803B317CE9C6A8A4D50.description:
Newton’s Second Law
in Rotational Form

EBBDC07B0C064542887AB400D7EA4321.description:
A rotational corollary to Newton’s second law
states that if the torques exerted on a rigid
system are not balanced, the system’s angular
velocity must be changing.

FEDF1FDA5E79407D8528E6B2BA617666.description:
The rotational analog of Newton’s first law
is that a system will have a constant angular
velocity only if the net torque exerted on
the system is zero.

6EBF24E0954C4CFD8753743ED43EB653.description:
Rotational equilibrium is a configuration of
torques such that the net torque exerted on
the system is zero.

5D384F2F470D47AEBD69F816828BFBD0.description:
Free-body and force diagrams describe the
nature of the forces and torques exerted on
an object or rigid system.

CB9F9A9E68E14F89827B7F1CAFB4154D.description:
A system may exhibit rotational equilibrium
(constant angular velocity) without being in
translational equilibrium, and vice versa.

0C9AC107EDE44B54A15AE49F0EF5124F.description:
Describe the conditions
under which a system’s
angular velocity remains
constant.

FCDA6918B0FE49898D38FB4BB0AE8607.description:
Rotational Equilibrium
and Newton’s First
Law in Rotational Form

8A5936A6ECE5437C958A468241D6D420.description:
The parallel axis theorem uses the following
equation to relate the rotational inertia of a rigid
system about any axis that is parallel to an axis
through its center of mass:
I Icm Md2

803AA9EA398C41D69AEB9CBE793267A2.description:
A rigid system’s rotational inertia in a given
plane is at a minimum when the rotational axis
passes through the system’s center of mass.

576D82CA829640E89BD21156177A2337.description:
Describe the rotational inertia
of a rigid system rotating
about an axis that does not
pass through the system’s
center of mass.

0701F9ACE7C14493AEA13922C255E2C0.description:
For a solid that can be considered as a
collection of differential masses, dm, the solid’s
rotational inertia can be calculated using the
equation
I r dm 2 = ∫ ,
where r is the perpendicular distance from dm
to the axis of rotation.

C87989B6756C480E88589AEAC4C29D9A.description:
The total rotational inertia of a collection
of objects about an axis is the sum of the
rotational inertias of each object about that
axis.

2FEA37CAE479467F9E8ABBADBE9F9503.description:
The rotational inertia of an object rotating
a perpendicular distance r from an axis is
described by the equation
I mr 2 = .

777C987498BC451D96845DCF03D5CB15.description:
Rotational inertia measures a rigid system’s
resistance to changes in rotation and is related
to the mass of the system and the distribution
of that mass relative to the axis of rotation.

753033ECE579420F83C360797340EC00.description:
Describe the rotational inertia
of a rigid system relative to a
given axis of rotation.

034D83E38B274F0C88A384748A95B27F.description:
The direction of the vector resulting from
the cross-product of vectors A

 and B

 can




 is



 and

A

1519C788D59548C6837BBD3D890C3112.description:
The torque exerted on a rigid system about
a chosen pivot point by a given force is
described by
τ = ×r F   
.

8A45CBB62B644C10B45358E72324B4B1.description:
Similar to free-body diagrams, force
diagrams represent the relative magnitude
and direction of the forces exerted on a
rigid system. Force diagrams also depict
the location at which those forces are
exerted relative to the axis of rotation.

8011C82B16154259A20BA2F34CF9115B.description:
Force diagrams are similar to free-body
diagrams and are used to analyze the
torques exerted on a rigid system.

AAB49066FFAB40999603B21403945E60.description:
Torques can be described using force
diagrams.

8DF264F3A9CD47C2A92F26769E1D6451.description:
Describe the torques exerted
on a rigid system.

FE197557DA3D4F6CA924B9AEB3F45D2D.description:
The lever arm is the perpendicular distance
from the axis of rotation to the line of action of
the exerted force.

328CC10EDF78411DA954A34E73FAE83D.description:
Torque results only from the force component
perpendicular to the position vector from the
axis of rotation to the point of application of the
force.

5F209AF3B9234C759C4A423D0DFF9476.description:
Identify the torques exerted
on a rigid system.

0EE42932A55D44488DBD04ACD7A81488.description:
For a rigid system, all points within that system
have the same angular velocity and angular
acceleration.

2DA5233BF2B6466BAD3F66269DC844B8.description:
Derived relationships of linear velocity and of
the tangential component of acceleration to
their respective angular quantities are given by
the following equations:

D1D2E1FD96214BE69E0881917EDDA463.description:
For a point at a distance r from a fixed axis of
rotation, the linear distance s traveled by the
point as the system rotates through an angle
∆θ is given by the equation ∆ =s r∆θ .

675CF59B575B4CD2BE61B614366FB939.description:
Describe the linear motion
of a point on a rotating rigid
system that corresponds to
the rotational motion of that
point, and vice versa.

2CBE42B9BB3A479BAEB77FEC48973FCA.description:
Graphs of angular displacement, angular
velocity, and angular acceleration as
functions of time can be used to find the
relationships between those quantities.

626F8493A4E24CD49E3B878F9BF5CC7B.description:
For constant angular acceleration, the
mathematical relationships between
angular displacement, angular velocity, and
angular acceleration can be described with
the following equations:
ω ω α
θ θ ω α
ω ω α θ( )

C4E4E14E9C7D4E5FA9ACC8FBAB86FA95.description:
Angular displacement, angular velocity,
and angular acceleration around one axis
are analogous to linear displacement,
velocity, and acceleration in one dimension
and demonstrate the same mathematical
relationships.

34F6960A2D374F83B9649E0D9E6C54BF.description:
Angular acceleration is the rate at which
angular velocity changes with respect to time.

6667B44DC6494EB990EC8DB79B657543.description:
Angular velocity is the rate at which angular
position changes with respect to time.

02EB26E6D40D4E96A8052C2E42A11604.description:
If the rotation of a system about an axis
may be well described using the motion of
the system’s center of mass, the system
may be treated as a single object. For
example, the rotation of Earth about its
axis may be considered negligible when
considering the revolution of Earth about
the center of mass of the Earth-Sun
system.

BC3E9DA214364902A20DBAD2D1852F84.description:
One direction of angular displacement
about an axis of rotation — clockwise or
counterclockwise — is typically indicated
as mathematically positive, with the
other direction becoming mathematically
negative.

3B30DB5E555B46048140C429F834AD16.description:
A rigid system is one that holds its shape
but in which different points on the system
move in different directions during rotation.
A rigid system cannot be modeled as an
object.

731AFD0E0B0E44BB8CE5B97F083EF49E.description:
Angular displacement is the measurement of
the angle, in radians, through which a point on a
rigid system rotates about a specified axis.

3B4E6FF8E6D3432A9F2D9310DDEE97B9.description:
Describe the rotation of a
system with respect to time
using angular displacement,
angular velocity, and angular
acceleration.

865B3433A011444AAB287FF31D9A88F0.description:
In a perfectly inelastic collision, the objects
stick together and move with the same velocity
after the collision.

0304CFD44CF94957B6605E018587FC26.description:
In an inelastic collision, some of the initial
kinetic energy is not restored to kinetic energy
but is transformed by nonconservative forces
into other forms of energy.

3CF7F82599D74B5C92698373879744F0.description:
An inelastic collision between objects is one
in which the total kinetic energy of the system
decreases.

0CB0271CB0144343B1CF2485C7620E9F.description:
In an elastic collision, the final kinetic energies
of each of the objects within the system may
be different from their initial kinetic energies.

98808817C2DB4E508F7DA71409213300.description:
An elastic collision between objects is one in
which the initial kinetic energy of the system is
equal to the final kinetic energy of the system.

F975EE4DDD34415CB5FC3CE454882291.description:
Describe whether an
interaction between objects
is elastic or inelastic.

22C9B46F640B445F8FC1A4D52ED7E39D.description:
If the net external force on the selected system
is nonzero, momentum is transferred between
the system and the environment.

8EB3CC18DDEC40D9B5C9D020AC0C0A8C.description:
If the net external force on the selected system
is zero, the total momentum of the system is
constant.

ABA18B6567B3440D8CF62EBEB0236C02.description: Momentum is conserved in all interactions.

B078B7D294464F9C844C60D05DA0894D.description:
Describe how the selection
of a system determines
whether the momentum of
that system changes.

5F460E9185D545AAAE3CD87BD3912BC7.description:
Correct application of conservation of
momentum can be used to determine the
velocity of a system immediately before and
immediately after collisions or explosions.

5F51175F3BB145C2AF211E54279429B8.description:
If the total momentum of a system
changes, that change will be equivalent to
the impulse exerted on the system.

6E86D1C8535740359B324C726B1BA8DE.description:
A system may be selected so that the total
momentum of that system is constant.

65BD173805134B4E8D76C99613D5FB25.description:
The impulse exerted by one object on a
second object is equal and opposite to the
impulse exerted by the second object on
the first. This is a direct result of Newton’s
third law.

1AD3D2B9BB8748EF89ED67EE2D30A70A.description:
In the absence of net external forces, any
change to the momentum of an object within
a system must be balanced by an equivalent
and opposite change of momentum elsewhere
within the system. Any change to the momentum
of a system is due to a transfer of momentum
between the system and its surroundings.

87C501AB41EB42F68B7B659E78BB2E55.description:
The total momentum of a system is the sum of
the momenta of the system’s constituent parts.

709B250EDC7E4FBB9F0C95E05A0BC97B.description:
The velocity of a system’s center of mass
is constant in the absence of a net external
force.

792AA65B0307498BAB7D1B019EBDE1A7.description:
For a collection of objects, the velocity of a
system’s center of mass can be calculated
using the equation

6C3EB5CA25C34F85AA38986439C58ED8.description:
A collection of objects with individual momenta
can be described as one system with one
center-of-mass velocity.

FCBE3E00484C4D64B2275026BD74E36C.description:
Describe the behavior of a
system using conservation of
linear momentum.

4C2427B3AF36434C8CCBF0A5DB2A4880.description:
The impulse–momentum theorem also
describes the behavior of a system in
which the velocity is constant but the mass
changes with respect to time.

C03980A6148045749190C9491CB32F76.description:
Newton’s second law of motion is a direct
result of the impulse–momentum theorem
applied to systems with constant mass.

895F6F9B40034CB5A3842AEFF57A781B.description:
The impulse exerted on an object is equal
to the object’s change in momentum.

2052494F830E45159EDA5ADEC8469E2E.description:
The impulse–momentum theorem relates the
impulse delivered to an object and the object’s
change in momentum.

8E78C87D963843B390DB463708187A3C.description:
Change in momentum is the difference
between a system’s final momentum and its
initial momentum.

A2CFB081D7324992A350FAFA4852F88B.description:
Describe the relationship
between the impulse exerted
on an object or system and
the change in momentum of
the object or system.

0192EB0E48C74D75BC295AA9C483A30C.description:
The net external force exerted on a system is
equal to the slope of a graph of the momentum
of the system as a function of time.

4627C7D51A8F4B6F93E2281EB4EACF03.description:
The impulse delivered to a system by a net
external force is equal to the area under the
curve of a graph of the net external force
exerted on the system as a function of time.

F5BDEA9F289B47C08DA093DE0A51E08C.description:
Impulse is a vector quantity and has the same
direction as the net force exerted on the
system.

77703C3D461B4850BCDCB7045521969E.description:
Impulse is defined as the integral of a force
exerted on an object or system over a time
interval.

101F9102AB5C49C18EF95F4B716C1F66.description:
The rate of change of a system’s momentum is
equal to the net external force exerted on that
system.

3F3811BA94294BEBB9C3653334BA3E43.description:
Describe the impulse
delivered to an object or
system.

D6465D9133BF449BB6FAE1251C5389C6.description:
An explosion is a model for an interaction
in which forces internal to the system move
objects within that system apart.

A1EB7A276D6F4177927F85949F9CCB4A.description:
As only the initial and final states of a
collision are analyzed, the object model
may be used to analyze collisions.

1B51B17150C44E2A983EB4A097BB77F1.description:
A collision is a model for an interaction
where the forces exerted between the
involved objects in the system are much
larger than the net external force exerted
on those objects during the interaction.

3D13750F6F5E4188BE910AD16619ED12.description:
Momentum can be used to analyze collisions
and explosions.

00E4913143AB4D2282752EA71107C7E7.description:
Momentum is a vector quantity and has the
same direction as the velocity.

185B8C0CD3D847DDB2E819DA6F75E695.description:
Linear momentum is defined by the equation
p m= v  
.

CC0B3C4D78324B5291B98AB1B9242879.description:
Describe the linear
momentum of an object or
system.

5BA8AF13E7C047A3BC2C83A23F9DC182.description:
The instantaneous power delivered to an
object by the component of a constant
force parallel to the object’s velocity can be
described with the derived equation

FE87C62E3D3546FDBE7659F615D8F804.description:
The instantaneous power delivered to an
object by a force is given by the equation

5988C1305FB74E23A657833C79A742F0.description:
Because work is the change in energy of an
object or system due to a force, average power
is the total work done, divided by the time
during which that work was done.

F894B5CDFB454BD28AAA05C56BC6254C.description:
Average power is the amount of energy being
transferred or converted, divided by the time it
took for that transfer or conversion to occur.

D16DE66160EC47AF83BCB7598A7F93EC.description:
Power is the rate at which energy changes with
respect to time, either by transfer into or out
of a system or by conversion from one type to
another within a system.

E88A1C236F9746D8BE4F4F704D7E7F7C.description:
Describe the transfer of
energy into, out of, or within a
system in terms of power.

95E5A815407A407582717FA8549A85E0.description:
If the work done on a selected system is
nonzero, energy is transferred between the
system and the environment.

4F23393B28DC4FDE93A289D6E5D822BF.description:
If the work done on a selected system is zero
and there are no nonconservative interactions
within the system, the total mechanical energy
of the system is constant.

9767E924C98F4FE2AE9675290E4B679C.description: Energy is conserved in all interactions.

5E0B4065473E40D2B5E22A51412532CB.description:
Describe how the selection of
a system determines whether
the energy of that system
changes.

6A913BCB9A5E4C20A317F148F9D2C8D7.description:
If the total energy of a system changes,
that change will be equivalent to the energy
transferred into or out of the system.

0F432DF34DBA4040B85CE19E52FADFC1.description:
A system may be selected so that the total
energy of that system is constant.

3DE9E0CAB4204A138C504170543F41B0.description:
Any change to a type of energy within a system
must be balanced by an equivalent change of
other types of energies within the system or by
a transfer of energy between the system and
its surroundings.

745D64CA09A9482EB04D332A6ADBCBE0.description:
Mechanical energy is the sum of a system’s
kinetic and potential energies.

76F4913D16764A8B9308100EB98A0C92.description:
Describe the behavior of a
system using conservation of
mechanical energy principles.

F30342017C234ACDB43410AD335DA37F.description:
A system that contains objects that interact
via conservative forces or that can change its
shape reversibly may have both kinetic and
potential energies.

ED3333C9A9434857AA792EAC63DEEEE9.description:
A system composed of only a single object can
only have kinetic energy.

EE18790791BF4FEBB1D78EE5AA941C6F.description:
Describe the energies
present in a system.

381D6EF75EBD4632AFC6543573928269.description:
The total potential energy of a system
containing more than two objects is the sum
of the potential energy of each pair of objects
within the system.

45B5DF2FB3254A1BAF3D73C98F5B53DB.description:
Because the gravitational field near the
surface of a planet is nearly constant, the
change in gravitational potential energy in
a system consisting of an object with mass
m and a planet with gravitational field of
magnitude g when the object is near the
surface of the planet may be approximated
by the equation
U mg y ∆ =g ∆ .

D9B0C8A0BAC641439119E5BB44110B75.description:
The general form for the gravitational
potential energy of a system consisting of
two approximately spherical distributions of
mass (e.g., moons, planets, or stars) is given
by the equation
U G m m
r g
1 2 = − .

5818F641D1F943E9A4947DB52009708B.description:
The elastic potential energy of an ideal
spring is given by the following equation,
where Δx is the distance the spring has
been stretched or compressed from its
equilibrium length.

506FB0FF69134B92A4B22B58D34E658C.description:
The potential energy of common physical
systems can be described using the physical
properties of that system.

D4613694E98D451DB4263090C1867AEA.description:
In a given dimension, unstable equilibrium
positions occur at locations where the
potential energy as a function of position in
that dimension has a local maximum.

EA5AC2356931441D82EA76562C3579C0.description:
In a given dimension, stable equilibrium
positions exist at locations where the
potential energy as a function of position in
that dimension has a local minimum.

38B44AB54492424192403BA82A9B5944.description:
Unstable equilibrium is a location at
which a small displacement in an object’s
position results in a force exerted on the
object in the same direction as the small
displacement, accelerating the object away
from the equilibrium position.

A2E536DCF5914E08A57D79440BCD2725.description:
Stable equilibrium is a location at which a
small displacement in an object’s position
results in a force exerted on the object
opposite to the direction of the small
displacement, accelerating the object back
toward the equilibrium position.

150216F2C5194DD4B1C517038804DD83.description:
Graphs of a system’s potential energy as
a function of its position can be useful in
determining physical properties of that system.

763297CFDE4248E781707C86C1B0D101.description:
The conservative forces exerted on a system
in a single dimension can be determined using
the slope of the system’s potential energy with
respect to position in that dimension; these
forces point in the direction of decreasing
potential energy.

7386096008A54554BAC6721B43A071C2.description:
The relationship between conservative forces
exerted on a system and the system’s potential
energy is
U F r dr cf

b

.

B06A0E6EBBE544DC9EC2389B269F181C.description:
The definition of zero potential energy for
a given system is a decision made by the
observer considering the situation to simplify
or otherwise assist in analysis.

0951BAB10F574CC694EF30435B623B13.description:
Potential energy is a scalar quantity associated
with the position of objects within a system.

1676FDF6A49541E5B9A42135EB0B63A4.description:
A system composed of two or more objects
has potential energy if the objects within that
system only interact with each other through
conservative forces.

D8CCD7F4A1F94CE1AB112AFF4F8E5612.description:
Describe the potential energy
of a system.

BC20B4128C8A4A9396E0511319A98264.description:
Work is equal to the area under the curve of a
graph of F|| as a function of displacement.

DA1A63AF634241DC83C047ABF809EA07.description:
The energy dissipated by friction is typically
equated to the force of friction times the
length of the path over which the force is
exerted.

6B5B9AC5643545DC8F24FA4C92EC512A.description:
If the system’s center of mass and the
point of application of the force move the
same distance when a force is exerted on a
system, then the system may be modeled
as an object, and only the system’s kinetic
energy can change.

B9A4FD277D6A4E1FA1C386143395E6BD.description:
An external force may change the
configuration of a system. The component
of the external force parallel to the
displacement times the displacement of
the point of application of the force gives
the change in kinetic energy of the system.

BCF68C06C77C433CB4A60DC813186891.description:
The work–energy theorem states that the
change in an object’s kinetic energy is equal to
the sum of the work (net work) being done by
all forces exerted on the object.

CDAFE949D2C542028B89CD0066A8153E.description:
The component of the force exerted on a
system perpendicular to the direction of
the displacement of the system’s center
of mass can change the direction of the
system’s motion without changing the
system’s kinetic energy.

AED0CEA3562540EDA0A83C9EF47D363B.description:
If the component of the force exerted on a
system that is parallel to the displacement
is constant, the work done on the system by
the force is given by the derived equation
W F = = 
d Fdcosθ.

B375CA5DF7904089ACB298DBC407D141.description:
Only the component of the force exerted on
a system that is parallel to the displacement
of the point of application of the force will
change the system’s total energy.

0B7F9B02CE224F68A448F7C0AA3AE15E.description:
The dot product between two vectors,
A

and B

, results in a scalar quantity of
magnitude
A B⋅ = ABcosθ   .

5DDED7D4B9774177A7B25F3D8FB860CC.description:
The work done on an object by a variable force
is calculated using
W F r dr a
b
= ⋅ ∫ ( )
 
,
where the integral is taken over the path from
point a to point b.

61F8D4FC1C5A400FB7AC7F34192A6903.description:
The most common nonconservative forces
are friction and air resistance.

524E19C278814BAEAF7F3B4F88125C88.description:
The work done by a nonconservative force
is path-dependent.

D66DE5236DCD4E69A0D78B87C153A7D7.description:
Potential energies are associated only with
conservative forces.

FF6EB29A9C7E4EA9B70E971C452CC2D0.description:
The work done by a conservative force on
a system—or the change in the potential
energy of the system—will be zero if the
system returns to its initial configuration.

F60C617AA11246539573606AA12EA365.description:
The work done by a conservative force
exerted on a system is path-independent
and only depends on the initial and final
configurations of that system.

837FDACFC078448B89A633C2979752D2.description:
Work is the amount of energy transferred into
or out of a system by a force exerted on that
system over a distance.

84E72794B683423684CB1C82A13C7F7C.description:
Describe the work done on
an object or system by a
given force or collection of
forces.

1E5034AC1F864E10804696A4D1EAE48A.description:
Different observers may measure different
values of the translational kinetic energy of an
object, depending on the observer’s frame of
reference.

13EF7862070845359DFED70510844706.description: Translational kinetic energy is a scalar quantity.

F35D74B64EA6479ABA296D2F154387B2.description:
An object’s translational kinetic energy is given
by the equation

A8BE2F58A48D4BD7B8839C176D04BD9A.description:
Describe the translational
kinetic energy of an object in
terms of the object’s mass
and velocity.

B0C92E8CCF3B410DB47237B73694D0B0.description:
For a satellite in circular orbit around a central
body, the satellite’s centripetal acceleration
is caused only by gravitational attraction.
The period and radius of the circular orbit are
related to the mass of the central body.

190AC287790B4392BF7C2912215A33B6.description:
Describe circular orbits using
Kepler’s third law.

47F5991D33A944599047A7A6B1012A74.description:
For an object traveling at a constant speed
in a circular path, the period is given by the
derived equation

5760F226C7C44426B1595F18B73C01C0.description:
The rate at which an object is completing
revolutions is defined as frequency, f.

92EA535ED6BB4A709658EE2C187549C8.description:
The time to complete one full circular path,
one full rotation, or a full cycle of oscillatory
motion is defined as period, T.

B85C46C458F64E338D42E69E8BD416D8.description:
The revolution of an object traveling in a circular
path at a constant speed (uniform circular motion)
can be described using period and frequency.

6F0FE72D84FA41CDA2A7EFF31B09C557.description:
The net acceleration of an object moving in
a circle is the vector sum of the centripetal
acceleration and tangential acceleration.

FF768BC4EF054D488F43379A776076E9.description:
Tangential acceleration is the rate at which
an object’s speed changes and is directed
tangent to the object’s circular path.

4FE537F981B74C38A7B28DD45E26B887.description:
A component of tension contributes to the
net force producing centripetal acceleration
experienced by a conical pendulum.

E1BDA5C9E9BE4233AAF8E1A1BB923E8D.description:
Components of the static friction force and
the normal force can contribute to the net
force producing centripetal acceleration of
an object traveling in a circle on a banked
surface.

6FC647D49AC042C78578B0B716D8BB90.description:
At the top of a vertical, circular loop, an
object requires a minimum speed to
maintain circular motion. At this point, and
with this minimum velocity, the gravitational
force is the only force that causes the
centripetal acceleration.

8E1836AFD5B543A7A662FCBD1E3519B6.description:
Centripetal acceleration can result from
a single force, more than one force, or
components of forces that are exerted on an
object in circular motion.

3AF06814FBCE494DBD918BFB10C070D5.description:
Centripetal acceleration is directed toward
the center of an object’s circular path.

068F0F901EA843DC9FB8B5C3158E8DEA.description:
The magnitude of centripetal acceleration
for an object moving in a circular path is
the ratio of the object’s tangential speed
squared to the radius of the circular path.

7182B4659EC641178CF19F720200BA20.description:
Centripetal acceleration is the component of
an object’s acceleration directed toward the
center of the object’s circular path.

2B6809FF7A7D484FAC0C16A104060313.description:
Describe the motion of an
object traveling in a circular
path.

C543391AF6664038B45F8FE2CC0229CE.description:
Terminal velocity is defined as the maximum
speed achieved by an object moving under the
influence of a constant force and a resistive
force that are exerted on the object in opposite
directions. The terminal condition is reached
when the net force exerted on the object is zero.

D95834B2325546509453D1BA86557AA5.description:
The position, velocity, and acceleration
as functions of time of an object under
the influence of a resistive force of the
form F kv r = −
 
 are exponential and have
asymptotes that are determined by the
initial conditions of the object and the
forces exerted on the object.

AD8E984B51684C94975212EEE2BCBE93.description:
The acceleration or position of a moving
object that is subject to a velocity-dependent
force may be determined using initial
conditions of the object and methods of
calculus, once a function for velocity is
determined.

303CC8B4ECB840C48A56075EF81C3B0D.description:
Using the method of separation of variables,
the velocity can be determined by integrating
over the proper limits of integration.

CB4756F9CD6440F78DABC63ED9A74963.description:
Applying Newton’s second law to an object
upon which a resistive force is exerted results
in a differential equation for velocity.

32808FBA152549DABD629F8AAAB7263C.description:
resistive force is defined as a velocitydependent force in the opposite direction of an
object’s velocity, for example:
  F k = − v

81F96BE6D7C4434683D3C77A6C2F20AA.description:
Describe the motion of an
object subject to a resistive
force.

FABD524F4B894CBFA22EDBD1C4926BB0.description:
The equivalent spring constant of a set of
springs arranged in parallel is the sum of
the individual spring constants.

44B70AAF7A2C4AEDBA684290D6F6FB11.description:
The equivalent spring constant of a set of
springs arranged in series is smaller than
the smallest constituent spring constant.

D947704E75614AB989FAE18EC574FB6C.description:
The inverse of the equivalent spring
constant of a set of springs in series is
equal to the sum of the inverses of the
individual spring constants.

4D855D1E7D614838BE5591D30CB0C634.description:
A collection of springs that exert forces on
an object may behave as though they were
a single spring with an equivalent spring
constant keq.

6CF8749B21E3452AA65F8C4A2BC4FCA6.description:
Describe the equivalent
spring constant of a
combination of springs
exerting forces on an object.

E7007A9217304EC599D912F77CCFE6DD.description:
The force exerted on an object by a spring
is always directed towards the equilibrium
position of the object–spring system.

37AA3A55D4B64C8386089320A8E0F74D.description:
The magnitude of the force exerted by an ideal
spring on an object is given by Hooke’s law:
F k x

E9F120B97A6641C5BEDAE40C37274620.description:
An ideal spring has negligible mass and exerts
a force that is proportional to the change in its
length as measured from its relaxed length. A
nonideal spring either has nonnegligible mass
or exerts a force that is not proportional to
the change in its length as measured from its
relaxed length.

B9802452D43A41D996F8C94C4879CF67.description:
Describe the force exerted on
an object by an ideal spring.

F65551D9C59D4206A2D1A66827F07247.description:
The coefficient of static friction is typically
greater than the coefficient of kinetic friction
for a given pair of surfaces.

E8D6659BDF094A0DB255DF9E0DC3DEFB.description:
There exists a maximum value for which
static friction will prevent an object from
slipping on a given surface.

987D15932FE54833861B0F88E60ABBDE.description:
Slipping and sliding refer to situations in
which two surfaces are moving relative to
each other.

F82EA51F6E6D497D977C4CB54C9ED70C.description:
Static friction adopts the value and direction
required to prevent an object from slipping or
sliding on a surface.

3A75FF1AEED54058A1FE300E80EB51DF.description:
Static friction may occur between the
contacting surfaces of two objects that are not
moving relative to each other.

AA0A8D98D4744B2F98ADC94142F19D00.description:
Describe static friction
between two surfaces.

BB5DBA9F3CC9417D8DE0B12D306EEB22.description:
Normal force is the perpendicular
component of the force exerted on an
object by the surface with which it is
in contact; it is directed away from the
surface.

7863A71DC7DA46CB860146ACE064D986.description:
The coefficient of kinetic friction depends
on the material properties of the surfaces
that are in contact.

B8415E9B9F044D3E914EC8A222371ED5.description:
The magnitude of the kinetic friction force
exerted on an object is the product of the
normal force the surface exerts on the object
and the coefficient of kinetic friction.

0ADBED66741C442FAD05196C225E2831.description:
The force of friction between two surfaces
does not depend on the size of the surface
area of contact.

1F650FCB23DD40E6B4C415821FAB478B.description:
The kinetic friction force is exerted in a
direction opposite the motion of each
surface relative to the other surface.

5C8FA96A0E22411698F73EA643BABAB2.description:
Kinetic friction occurs when two surfaces in
contact move relative to each other.

74E11799731E466BA878703E7F150B86.description:
Describe kinetic friction
between two surfaces.

8D6C966FE62A4DB88DA9316A7D8F8D6D.description:
The gravitational force exerted on an object
within a uniform sphere can be shown to be
proportional to the object’s distance from the
sphere’s center.

782D1F0B3BC94908B5A316AC5900DDF6.description:
The partial mass of a sphere that
contributes to the net gravitational force
exerted on an object within that sphere is
the portion of the sphere’s mass located a
distance less than or equal to the object’s
distance from the center of the sphere and
can be calculated using the density of the
sphere.

A5196741081B4C40A6E280EA0505CB2D.description:
An object inside a sphere of uniform density
experiences a net gravitational force from
only a partial mass of the sphere.

259238F04ACE4904A6EBF876C144A1B8.description:
The net gravitational force exerted on an
object outside a thin spherical shell can be
determined by treating the shell as a single
massive object located at the center of the
shell.

B20A01702A6B424E8A9A0C2B8272DC54.description:
The net gravitational force exerted on an
object inside a thin spherical shell is zero.

58BC28551D4E48C1800A2AE93C4AE0A0.description:
Newton’s shell theorem describes the net
gravitational force exerted on an object by a
uniform spherical shell of mass.

F833DB2631D04E2CA522DA479CFA4AE5.description:
The net gravitational force exerted on an
object by a uniform spherical distribution of
mass is the sum of the individual forces from
small differential masses that comprise the
distribution.

EF50051BF5B345928A9A4E79901A60CF.description:
Describe the gravitational
force exerted on an object
by a uniform spherical
distribution of mass.

CA21169C825A489D913F8CE1A1AD34A8.description:
Inertial mass and gravitational mass have been
experimentally verified to be equivalent.

753FF35237604C4CB5154ABFEA5C1058.description:
Gravitational mass is related to the force of
attraction between two systems with mass.

5A0EB5F978CB41F396B8D80468709F59.description:
Objects have inertial mass, or inertia, a
property that determines how much an object’s
motion resists changes when interacting with
another object.

EB946477C3DA47708DE912FE72FD0C9C.description:
The equivalence principle states that an
observer in a noninertial reference frame is
unable to distinguish between an object’s
apparent weight and the gravitational force
exerted on the object by a gravitational field.

40514F0FE2B148E38BB20570E0FC2A3C.description:
A system appears weightless when there are
no forces exerted on the system or when the
force of gravity is the only force exerted on the
system.

ACCA679F8B5F450AB6152D17C2D8AAF6.description:
If the system is accelerating, the apparent
weight of the system is not equal to the
magnitude of the gravitational force exerted on
the system.

AA9D49A46AB34AE6A4CF966C6E8C4E32.description:
The magnitude of the apparent weight of a
system is the magnitude of the normal force
exerted on the system.

7E9A78477D71483BB45627F36A62281F.description:
Describe the conditions
under which the magnitude of
a system’s apparent weight is
different from the magnitude
of the gravitational force
exerted on that system.

19D79AD19BE64A89806526F3DAFF7EE5.description:
Near the surface of Earth, the strength of the
gravitational field is
g ≈10 N kg.

23A8C278AB38499F9B63598EFAEBD267.description:
If the gravitational force between two systems’
centers of mass has a negligible change as the
relative position of the two systems changes,
the gravitational force can be considered
constant at all points between the initial and
final positions of the systems.

9D31C8A45D804D07B931B7293437BAA2.description:
Describe situations in which
the gravitational force can be
considered constant.

F43CE7B396A24C1BB2C3F0015C81F6F8.description:
The gravitational force exerted by an
astronomical body on a relatively small nearby
object is called weight.

2D446E557F53472EBDF5EE83DA98FF4D.description:
If the gravitational force is the only force
exerted on an object, the observed
acceleration of the object (in m/s
2
) is
numerically equal to the magnitude of the
gravitational field strength (in N/kg) at that
location.

F1FAC177D1394ACFB5C3367AF03C0F11.description:
The magnitude of the gravitational field
created by a system of mass M at a
point in space is equal to the ratio of the
gravitational force exerted by the system
on a test object of mass m to the mass of
the test object.

3B0C5EA7F3314F69BE268B2FFB9FC78C.description:
A field models the effects of a noncontact
force exerted on an object at various positions
in space.

EEAE77FD4BAC45C9B428C65055B800C9.description:
The gravitational force on a system can be
considered to be exerted on the system’s
center of mass.

2CEF861E0C434CCB9ACE61792BD18161.description:
The gravitational force is always exerted
along the line connecting the center of
mass of the two interacting systems.

BCD6519990D449D9A9492805EF96D1D8.description:
Newton’s law of universal gravitation describes
the gravitational force between two objects
or systems as directly proportional to each of
their masses and inversely proportional to the
square of the distance between the systems’
centers of mass.

A13482BE959F4187AD15AF46E959E85C.description:
Describe the gravitational
interaction between two
objects or systems with
mass.

768BEE24981D4F14AAA330BB10734DAC.description:
The velocity of a system’s center of mass will
only change if a nonzero net external force is
exerted on that system.

CDF21D9CCA774146903527DAB4A30326.description:
Newton’s second law of motion states that the
acceleration of a system’s center of mass has
a magnitude proportional to the magnitude of
the net force exerted on the system and is in
the same direction as that net force.

5FD4B5B6297D4919997DBC1AE620FFD1.description:
Unbalanced forces are a configuration of
forces such that the net force exerted on a
system is not equal to zero.

0C8B3A15919D442F8DAFDCA502297900.description:
Describe the conditions
under which a system’s
velocity changes.

846496E7605A47D9A8E3E36AA1E034B8.description:
An inertial reference frame is one from which
an observer would verify Newton’s first law of
motion.

D9F23564D8D045E0BC72CF42969D7576.description:
Forces may be balanced in one dimension
but unbalanced in another. The system’s
velocity will change only in the direction of the
unbalanced force.

2F1C59456DE04D6E86A8EA974FEA686B.description:
Newton’s first law states that if the net force
exerted on a system is zero, the velocity of that
system will remain constant.

572BD6D2B7684369ABA8AEDCA25F05E5.description:
Translational equilibrium is the configuration
of forces such that the net force exerted on a
system is zero.
Derived equation:
F 0

21652D1DF96D4785A88D00A39E94315D.description:
The net force on a system is the vector sum of
all forces exerted on the system.

3451BB477A3548C89CC247A0DA1510D8.description:
Describe the conditions
under which a system’s
velocity remains constant.

B7724A68607049DA9B27B262C7726BA6.description:
An ideal pulley is a pulley that has negligible
mass and rotates about an axle through its
center of mass with negligible friction.

76C15E709AB84CBF90F9A8A38D2C635D.description:
In a string with nonnegligible mass, tension
may not be the same at all points within the
string.

C54C7A09D38E4A0DAB612C38AF6F9B9D.description:
The tension in an ideal string is the same at
all points within the string.

02D1B8F4904746A5A4CEFAA1EDF2353F.description:
An ideal string has negligible mass and
does not stretch when under tension.

86958378AD124280A84AA618DCC51524.description:
Tension is the macroscopic net result of forces
that infinitesimal segments of a string, cable,
chain, or similar system exert on each other in
response to an external force.

7089F18591A2418EAE7CF7CB2A5F86B3.description:
Interactions between objects within a system
(internal forces) do not influence the motion of
a system’s center of mass.

3A03AA3771F840048D7DE0870CC727F1.description:
Newton’s third law describes the interaction of
two objects or systems in terms of the paired
forces that each exerts on the other.

3097B8B6863F46E38876AA7611A9FA86.description:
Describe the interaction
of two objects or systems
using Newton’s third law and
a representation of paired
forces exerted on each
object or system.

794097402CF34C1FA63835CDD3B898B7.description:
A coordinate system with one axis parallel to
the direction of acceleration of the object or
system simplifies the translation from freebody diagram to algebraic representation. For
example, in a free-body diagram of an object
on an inclined plane, it is useful to set one axis
parallel to the surface of the incline.

9618FDB5914543AC9A78A8DBE9AF2BDE.description:
Forces exerted on an object or system are
represented as vectors originating from the
representation of the center of mass, such as
a dot. A system is treated as though all of its
mass is located at the center of mass.

50F2FD7537184725AAA133E27122F2CF.description:
The free-body diagram of an object or system
shows each of the forces exerted on the object
or system by the environment.

412AF42BC97F48FBBBA76FC67DE20061.description:
Free-body diagrams are useful tools for
visualizing forces being exerted on a single
object or system and for determining the
equations that represent a physical situation.

510F19542F8B442C84FD2A61C7D6C211.description:
Describe the forces exerted
on an object or system using
a free-body diagram.

1CFFEF5E77074E5485E936F484CE22C4.description:
Contact forces describe the interaction of
an object or system touching another object
or system and are macroscopic effects of
interatomic electric forces.

66ED764DE84B4318A2918857A1A611E3.description:
An object or system cannot exert a net
force on itself.

3D8565ADDA984895A111756718489602.description:
A force exerted on an object or system is
always due to the interaction of that object
or system with another object or system.

419899091BE04AB193D6E80B360D4FFF.description:
Forces are vector quantities that describe the
interactions between objects or systems.

4CC1602DDAA247F7BB0C11E10AAAAC9E.description:
Describe a force as an
interaction between two
objects or systems

D57978AA29564732B5A689B903DECB1C.description:
A system can be modeled as a singular object
that is located at the system’s center of mass.

CF769DBCBC4C496CB1EC091851F00B73.description:
If a function of mass density is given for
a solid, the total mass can be determined
by integrating the mass density over
the length (one dimension), area (two
dimensions), or volume (three dimensions)
of the solid. For example:
M r total = ∫ ρ( )dV

BB20D9D35AED4131AB4ADF4B3F44B6C8.description:
The linear mass density of a rod or other
linear rigid body is the derivative of the
rod’s mass with respect to the position of
the differential mass element on the rigid
body.

83862DBCCF60474AAA6251570C043032.description:
For a nonuniform solid that can be considered
as a collection of differential masses, dm, the
solid’s center of mass can be calculated using
the equation
 
∫
∫ r = r dm
dm

7EBD356E5D784366B8E4599FF2A592D2.description:
The location of a system’s center of mass along a
given axis can be calculated using the equation
x

∑

2F9ED9C2978640DDAC74AB241AF249A5.description:
For objects or systems with symmetrical mass
distributions, the center of mass is located on
lines of symmetry.

EB3FAA62C06749DD9AACF3504C64FEAE.description:
Describe the location of a
system’s center of mass
with respect to the system’s
constituent parts.

00D517386BB74C7F86A6501F4B9654D4.description:
As variables external to a system are changed,
the system’s substructure may change.

7D1A560D3E954F019C16507EDC8F48CC.description:
The internal structure of a system affects the
analysis of that system.

C36F95F524AE4A85A6032A5DAC4388CD.description:
Individual objects within a chosen system may
behave differently from each other as well as
from the system as a whole.

12FB3A5D533640E6B3221BFD045007F3.description:
Systems may allow interactions between
constituent parts of the system and the
environment, which may result in the transfer of
energy or mass.

8F4C06268A604407B5E55284F76F4364.description:
If the properties or interactions of the
constituent objects within a system are not
important in modeling the behavior of the
macroscopic system, the system can itself be
treated as a single object.

86E065C4026042B4A61D08428339DEB1.description:
System properties are determined by the
interactions between objects within the
system.

B932973D17C04765A55F79E0A162983B.description:
Describe the properties and
interactions of a system.

74D9571482274070B7F7A9571356530C.description:
Projectile motion is a special case of twodimensional motion that has zero acceleration
in one dimension and constant, nonzero
acceleration in the second dimension.

766C16A0459F408DAD7462D8A09AFDFC.description:
Motion in one dimension may be changed
without causing a change in a perpendicular
dimension.

EB2E4024CBE24214AC2A34AD90C7695D.description:
Velocity and acceleration may be different in
each dimension and may be nonuniform.

DBB086005D4D4824ACAD933024FF79E9.description:
Motion in two or three dimensions can be
analyzed using one-dimensional kinematic
relationships if the motion is separated into
components.

E1682732D2534B5D80179025ECB423EC.description:
Describe the motion of an
object moving in two or three
dimensions.

387BE5323DBB402AA7EB1DF675694D1E.description:
Motion in Two or
Three Dimensions

DE19A12BC5A043A38116B1D237494317.description:
The acceleration of any object is the same
as measured from all inertial reference
frames.

C1622ADA98234A76801565A96CFD0CFA.description:
Combining the motion of an object and the
motion of an observer in a given reference
frame involves the addition or subtraction
of vectors.

FD17162264CB47E2BC4868FC83EC0D65.description:
The observed velocity of an object results from
the combination of the object’s velocity and
the velocity of the observer’s reference frame.

8670981C0DBD46AFB918864320E79F68.description:
Measurements from a given reference frame
may be converted to measurements from
another reference frame.

82AA303AB13C4A6094E79D7B962643B0.description:
Describe the motion of
objects as measured by
observers in different inertial
reference frames.

0E2B2A5DCEB94286B46EFEC739D3961A.description:
The choice of reference frame will determine
the direction and magnitude of quantities
measured by an observer in that reference
frame.

10B748924B0942E6B5F1566767284FA1.description:
Describe the reference frame
of a given observer.

5AB09922A94947CAAB18CFA1015E4F69.description:
The change in velocity of an object during a
time interval is equal to the area under the
curve of a graph of the acceleration of the
object as a function of time.

1F9DBB7770604D94921860FE4CEE577F.description:
The displacement of an object during a
time interval is equal to the area under the
curve of a graph of the object’s velocity as
a function of time (i.e., the area bounded by
the function and the horizontal axis for the
appropriate interval).

A283ABAA372E47D4BFAFF1FC1CCF7610.description:
An object’s instantaneous acceleration is
the rate of change of the object’s velocity,
which is equal to the slope of a line tangent
to a point on a graph of the object’s velocity
as a function of time.

F9DD9194C2BA4CEC8BED58B737E71EE9.description:
An object’s instantaneous velocity is the
rate of change of the object’s position,
which is equal to the slope of a line tangent
to a point on a graph of the object’s
position as a function of time.

AD465D1406C349EB82E9AE3E2091EBFD.description:
Graphs of position, velocity, and acceleration
as functions of time can be used to find the
relationships between those quantities.

BD82E7E22F234970B1B5AFF11BAD7009.description:
Near the surface of Earth, the vertical
acceleration caused by the force of gravity is
downward, constant, and has a measured value
approximately equal to
a g 10 m s g
2 = ≈ .

9212CA39D6784EE1AB189A4813D636EC.description:
For constant acceleration, three kinematic
equations can be used to describe
instantaneous linear motion in one dimension:

A26361814C11464D873A71D4400A2CC0.description:
Motion can be represented by motion
diagrams, figures, graphs, equations, and
narrative descriptions.

E34CA7709DD24E3B9F16060C3BFE524C.description:
Describe the position,
velocity, and acceleration
of an object using
representations of that
object’s motion.

3CA17FCC7C9A43D2B8314383EEECF90C.description:
Time-dependent functions and instantaneous
values of position, velocity, and acceleration
can be determined using differentiation and
integration.

74C9BDB2002D4F8BBDB61E7FF0494F02.description:
Instantaneous acceleration is the rate of
change of the object’s velocity, which is
equal to the derivative of velocity with
respect to time.

DCDB9631CADE49F68A17F34804586541.description:
Instantaneous velocity is the rate of change
of the object’s position, which is equal to
the derivative of position with respect to
time.

B12BC0E8D7444C5B8F42EBB93E695C04.description:
As the time interval used to calculate the
average value of a quantity approaches zero,
the average value of that quantity approaches
the value of the quantity at that instant, called
the instantaneous value.

0C76121390BB441C863B9452E8E5650A.description:
Describe the instantaneous
position, velocity, and
acceleration of an object as a
function of time.

FB66B8295AAF4CD9AEF647330F142A85.description:
Calculating average velocity or average
acceleration over a very small time interval
yields a value that is very close to the
instantaneous velocity or instantaneous
acceleration.

52BDF66A8AC041AE925D37460EF3A0F7.description:
An object is accelerating if either the
magnitude and/or direction of the object’s
velocity are changing.

CA17D5FC91ED4E5080AD29C4AC4307E9.description:
Average acceleration is the change in velocity
divided by the interval of time in which that
change in velocity occurs.

v
t

77B81BF80A0343E589372F71D6F3BB5E.description:
Average velocity is the displacement of an
object divided by the interval of time in which
that displacement occurs.
 
= ∆
∆
v
x
t

C4E2244A2AEA4BB5BC62075FE764B084.description:
Averages of velocity and acceleration are
calculated considering the initial and final
states of an object over an interval of time.

364B6A07187A4EB9B00A19267EB640DC.description:
Describe the average velocity
and acceleration of an object.

3622FADB997C42649C69D83784546ACD.description:
Displacement is the change in an object’s
position.
Relevant equation:
∆ = x x − x0

87722F2224B74B0B8FA46A772FFA7888.description:
When using the object model, the size, shape,
and internal configuration are ignored. The
object may be treated as a single point with
extensive properties such as mass and charge.

06C4BC2C5C3E4843866A1AEDE99C6213.description:
Describe a change in an
object’s position.

F8A0BDAEA5414497B306CA1DDBD974CD.description:
In a given one-dimensional coordinate system,
opposite directions are denoted by opposite
signs.

53583908D0E148B6BF08F2A255BFEF1A.description:
A resultant vector is the vector sum of the
addend vectors’ components.
Relevant equations:
  
   ( ) ( )

C A B i A B j

E7C25F489CC3463D9588BE4363D78E5A.description:
The position vector of a point is given by r

,
and the unit vector in the direction of the
position vector is denoted r.

5A166E1A2C674C6F8B3CDDFAEA2763C8.description:
Unit vector notation can be used to
represent vectors as the sum of their
constituent components in the x-, y-,
and z-directions, denoted by i
, j
, and k
,
respectively.

71195F4CB6D64073B6B8222C8C784625.description:
Vectors can be expressed in unit vector
notation or as a magnitude and a direction.

AE1FC8D6007D4A3FAF19C24A56C32631.description:
Distance and speed are examples of scalar
quantities, while position, displacement,
velocity, and acceleration are examples of
vector quantities.

AB73E29ADCB04F58B6FC50687C0F1475.description:
Vectors can be visually modeled as arrows with
appropriate direction and lengths proportional
to their magnitude.

6C76A9368693472DA83A8829299D4CC7.description:
Scalars are quantities described by magnitude
only; vectors are quantities described by both
magnitude and direction.

E3FC75E731864A669E3088923ADDD30E.description:
Describe a scalar or vector
quantity using magnitude and
direction, as appropriate.

51CFB96845AE4EF8A11A8FBA72ED20EB.description:
Justify or support a claim using
evidence from experimental data, physical
representations, or physical principles or
laws.

0872009A227D4824A19B0119CD50EA21.description:
Apply an appropriate law, definition,
theoretical relationship, or model to make a
claim.

30FDE5CE18A54B3B919618E573E63130.description:
Create experimental procedures
that are appropriate for a given scientific
question.

30452D001CAE4A7D9A731A73FDA2884F.description:
Scientific Questioning and
Argumentation: Describe experimental procedures, analyze data, and
support claims.

45D0D0FE3AA4437EA7FCCF79CF548A49.description:
Predict new values or factors of
change of physical quantities using
functional dependence between
variables.

26024D622F124D979C9EE9C60D1ABAB3.description:
Compare physical quantities
between two or more scenarios or
at different times and locations in a
single scenario.

D19F4426292343D7AF8D0FD49BF952FE.description:
Calculate or estimate an unknown
quantity with units from known
quantities, by selecting and following a
logical computational pathway

88811738684C4576818643A2355E69FE.description:
Derive a symbolic expression
from known quantities by selecting
and following a logical mathematical
pathway.

8C9E6E9938804F8ABE7660C5E2A399E7.description:
Mathematical Routines: Conduct analyses to derive, calculate, estimate, or
predict.

6C5EA60386C4468BA67800ECED8D0E37.description:
Create qualitative sketches of
graphs that represent features of a
model or the behavior of a physical
system.

4FC867AB2D5B46E7A7D43020FFA51C87.description:
Create quantitative graphs with
appropriate scales and units, including
plotting data.

7664C70CC4AC41C3B5ABD982950A0D5D.description:
Create diagrams, tables, charts,
or schematics to represent physical
situations.

CF355F92F7694E63966A93F71A3D6A02.description:
Creating Representations: Create representations that depict physical
phenomena.
